@andrewwheiss

Documentation and vignettes

Should the author(s) deem it appropriate, I agree to be acknowledged as a package reviewer (â€œrevâ€ role) in the package DESCRIPTION file.

  • Added @andrewwheis as reviewer role to DESCRIPTION

All vignettes worked great and were a perfect introduction to the package. It might be helpful to move up the vignette listing near the beginning of the README so that users can find them more easily.

  • Moved vignettes section up to above key functions (and just after install/API authorization)

Each function is generally very well documented. There are some sparsely documented functions like bearer_token() and invalidate_bearer() that seem to only be used internallyâ€”it might be useful to either add @keywords internal to the roxygen block or add additional documentation explaining what a bearer token is and including some examples.

  • Added @ keywords internal to invalidate_bearer()
  • Improved name/description, added more information about requirements and usage, and several examples to bearer_token()

Itâ€™s really helpful that the US and the world are baked into lookup_coords() (e.g.Â lookup_coords(â€œusaâ€)) so users donâ€™t need an API key for that. This should probably be documented, though. It caught me by surprise that â€œusaâ€ was working just fine and all other locations triggered a messageâ€”I only figured out why because I looked at the source code for lookup_coords(), and that has a huge all caps note about needing a Google Maps API key. (A future expansion could maybe include hardcoded boundaries for a bunch of other countries (perhaps make an internal lookup table of lat/long coordinates?) so the package is less US-centric and less dependent on another API.)

  • Document US/world coordinates in lookup_coords(). This can be found in the details section of lookup_coords()
  • Add other (less US-centric) defaults to lookup_coords(). Latitude and longitudes for major world cities are now hardwired in. This is documented in the details section of lookup_coords(). And Iâ€™ve added new automated tests for these as well.

The pkgdown site is great. It might be helpful (and recommended by rOpenSci) to add @family tags to roxygen documentation so that there are automatic groups of functions in the documentation and in the reference website.

  • Add @family tags for reference/function documentation grouping

Installation and testing

Testing doesnâ€™t work out of the box and it took me a while to figure out how to generate the /tests/testthat/twitter_tokens RDS file. When logged in through the embedded rstats2twitter app, running this created an auth token that the test suite can useâ€¦It might be useful to explain that process somewhere in the documentationâ€”not in the README though, since itâ€™s not something a typical user would do.

  • Added description of configuration/setup of test token. Iâ€™ve created a â€˜Github actionâ€™ for thisâ€“so forking {rtweet} should trigger a message about automated testing and working with encrypted keys on travis-ci

(FAILED) direct_messages: This is because the rstats2twitter app doesnâ€™t provide read-write DM access. It worked when I used my own auth token

  • Testing now checks for appropriate permissions.
  • As for the limited permissions, this was a concsious decision on my part. I limited write and DM-related permissions in tokens generated via rstats2twitter because I donâ€™t want to encourage or be associated with automated/spam/TOS-violating behaviors.

(FAILED) get_my_timeline: One test failed because rtweet:::home_user() not equal to â€œkearneymwâ€. Mikeâ€™s account is hardcoded in the tests and this test canâ€™t pass if someone is using a different account. I donâ€™t know what else could be done to test it though.

  • Agreed. This may have been possible back when I had a dedicated rtweet Twitter account, but that got shut down by Twitter (I learned you canâ€™t use multiple accounts/tokens to do the same thing the hard way), so Iâ€™m hesitant/careful not to further hurt my standing with them.

(FAILED) lookup_coords: This returns an error that seems unrelated to token issues and I donâ€™t know while itâ€™s failing

  • Edited test to check if an environment variable named GOOGLE exists and optionally replaces with empty for following test.

(FAILED) tweet_shot: This failed because I didnâ€™t have PhantomJS installed. The test worked after installing it. Running tweet_shot() interactively gives a note that it should be installed with webshot::install_phantomjs(), but this message is invisible when testing on a fresh system. PhantomJS isnâ€™t installed as a dependency when the package in installed, but thatâ€™s because itâ€™s not an R package. idk what the best way to handle this is, though, since itâ€™s 16+ MB and not handled automatically with R Â¯_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯

  • The webshot dependencies are especially difficult to configure in travis integrations. Since webshot is recommended and not required, Iâ€™ve changed the test to first check whether the webshot package is installed.

(FAILED) test-test_username-r: Like get_my_timeline, this failed because Mikeâ€™s account is hardcoded in. Again, I donâ€™t know what the best way to handle this is.

  • This may have been possible back when I had a dedicated rtweet Twitter account, but that got shut down by Twitter (I learned you canâ€™t use multiple accounts/tokens to do the same thing the hard way), so Iâ€™m hesitant/careful not to further hurt my standing with them.

Token creation and authentication

It might be helpful to more clearly explain the benefits of creating an app with tokens vs.Â just using the interactive browser-based token. Right now, the README says â€œYou may still choose to do this [create an app] (gives you more stability and permissions)â€, and the auth vignette explains how to do it, but there isnâ€™t any explanation of why users might want to do it. Later in the README, under â€œPost actions,â€ it explains that users would need their own app to post tweets and access DMs, but it could be helpful to have that information up above when describing authentication in general. It might even be helpful to have a table of sorts showing pros/cons/features available when using a private app vs.Â the embedded rstats2twitter app, like this maybe?

Task rstats2twitter user-app
Work interactively âœ… âœ…
Search/lookup tweets/users âœ… âœ…
Get friends/followers âœ… âœ…
Get timelines/favorites âœ… âœ…
Get lists/collections âœ… âœ…
Post tweets âŒ âœ…
Run package tests âŒ âœ…
Use Bearer token âŒ âœ…
Read/Write Direct Messages âŒ âœ…
  • Futher developed comparison table for embedded app versus user-created apps (now included in README) and added more description of pros/cons of creating a token in documentation.

The page for creating apps looks slightly different from the screenshots, and the direction to go to apps.twitter.com is out of dateâ€”according to Twitter, that aspect of developer accounts is getting sunset. Instead, the URL is now https://developer.twitter.com/en/apps .

  • Iâ€™ve updated the auth and FAQ vignettes to reflect the new developer portal. Iâ€™ve also updated the steps, labels, and screen shots in the auth vignette.

Community

  • Added .github/CONTRIBUTING.md and CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Creating an RStudio project .Rproj file could be helpful for encouraging package contributions, since it would enable RStudioâ€™s package building interface. ### rOpenSci-related issues

  • Removed .Rproj from .gitignore and added rtweet.Rproj 
* [Following rOpenSci's package guidelines](https://ropensci.github.io/dev_guide/building.html#creating-metadata-for-your-package), it might be helpful to use the **codemetar** package to generate a `codemeta.json` file.
  • Added codemeta.json file

  • Added repostatus badge!

  • Added rOpenSci badge!
